issues.title: Add outline of Security Considerations Topics/sub-sections
issues.author: rahelFain
issues.body:
Provide an outline of the topics that will be discussed in this document. 
This could also include a statement noting that use case specific security considerations will need to be specified in their protocol specification document(s).

comments.author: rahelFain
comments.body:
I began thinking of a few topics that could be included in the Security Considerations Section - but have listed them in this issue rather than a PR b/c I still have yet to discuss these with my co-authors. 

Potential Entries subsections to include:

1. Digital Emblems do not actively stop/defend against attacks: For emblems that indicate an asset's protected status, digital emblems can at best serve as a deterrent for attack - as there is no guarantee a would-be attacker will respect the laws, agreements or standards granting the asset its status. 

2. Plausible deniability surrounding whether or not emblem was seen, visible or verifiable at time of validation.

Note: This is by no means intended to be an exhaustive list of topics but rather a first brainstorm.

comments.author: amankin
comments.body: 3. For Digital Emblems that require Authentication of the Digital Emblem, origin authentication or other authentication of the Bearer, or Authorization of the Digital Emblem (the MUSTs in Section 3),  the threat model addressed is presentation of falsified Digital Emblems. Both 1 and 2 above will require addressing this threat model.

comments.author: ohmantics
comments.body: Several of the use cases would probably want to plan for forensics capabilities, such as a history of creation and modification of an emblem, associating it with internal references for identity of the creator/modifier, etc. This is not outward security, but merits some thinking about how external or encrypted-in-place metadata can be associated with an emblem.

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body: Partially addressed in #7

issues.title: Bearer and asset question
issues.author: amankin
issues.body: This is an issue raised to me by Bill Woodcock, as he's tied up right now, but the paraphrase is mine:  could we clarify if there is a difference in meaning between a bearer of a digital emblem versus an asset that bears a digital emblem?  Since we are thinking of our definitions very much as working definitions, can we think of these as the same and in some cases use "asset?"

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body: I have thought about this too. In my head, the difference between bearer and asset is similar as in syntax/semantics. The bearer is, e.g., a domain name. The asset that is marked is identified by the bearer, and, e.g., could be the webserver identified by that domain name. But I agree, the two terms could benefit from clarification.

comments.author: dkg
comments.body: I think all bearers are assets, but not all assets are bearers.  For example, an asset that doesn't have an emblem isn't a bearer.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
substantial discussion on the difference between an asset and a bearer. Some examples were given of likely differences.

action item to copy examples into comments in this issue.

ex: passport vs person it identifies, @dkg comments about things related to an asset, wetland might be an asset but not a bearer.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
Stuart Cuard quoted from Black's law dictionary "A bearer is a **person** who...."  (indicating that a bearer is considered distinct from the things getting the special treatment.)

distinction between the thing entitled to special treatment and what presents it?

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: Samit and Allison to propose text

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: Believed to be incorporated in -01

issues.title: More details on use cases and requirements
issues.author: felixlinker
issues.body:
This issue is practically me crossposting my comments on the mailing list: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/diem/nAX4K9D2HM5HNr92ozcQCs_J70o/

The use cases section is not detailed enough for actionable work in my opinion. We need to:

- Understand how each use case relates to the requirements on the architecture
- Decide whether use cases have received sufficient stakeholder evaluation and invite for that

The current version of the document is not specific enough to address both these goals.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: Example of the level of detail that @felixlinker proposes is in PR #5

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: @felixlinker since PR #5 was merged is this issue still relevant? If so, what is remaining to do?

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body: @rohanmahy Yes, this issue is still relevant. Other use cases still miss the level of detail that is provided for the IHL use case. Also, we're still missing an understanding of which use case received stakeholder evaluation. But I did not add this for the IHL use case either. I guess this is best discusse on list.

issues.title: Do we want to respect the 5 author suggested limit?
issues.author: rohanmahy

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
No. Whomever is holding the pen needs to publish new documents, do needs to be in the author list.
Figure out if/what the authors need to be at the end.   The IETF actively discourages authorship to indicate endorsement.
But, other entities have different rules, and if we need someone listed as an author, then we should facilitate this.

comments.author: ohmantics
comments.body: #19 resolves this by adding a contributors section and moving Jim to it with his permission, leaving us at 5 authors.

issues.title: Is there a need for forensic records of emblems for some emblem types?
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
Suggested by @amankin 

@felixlinker said they intended to address this in Section 4.5

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body: @amankin Regarding this issue, we intend to discuss this as "Proof of Presence" in the "Extensions" section. Is there anything you're missing from that section?

issues.title: Attacker and authorizing party roles and operations in use cases
issues.author: dkg
issues.body:
When describing a use case for a digital protocol, i'm used to seeing use cases presented from every party involved in a transaction.

For example, in digital id discussions, we need to talk about how a verifier operates, as well as how an issuer operates, and how a holder operates.

The use cases i'm seeing in the current document are all split out by talking about different bearer scenarios.

But i don't see any discussion of an attacker's perspective, or an authorizing party's perspective.  Should we detail those perspectives within each use case?  or should we detail them as their own distinct use case?

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body:
Thanks for suggesting that, dkg! What you raise here mirrors some issues I noticed when talking about the architecture to Jim on the hallway.

I think we should add those details to each use cases, but we should consider group very similar use cases together, and generalizing where possible. Depending on the feedback on individual use cases (e.g., press use case mostly received negative feedback), we might also save ourselves some work for use cases that we anticipate will not be in a WGLC draft.

issues.title: Diplomatic bag rules
issues.author: ohmantics
issues.body:
This use case was in early discussions but did not make it into this draft.

They're covered in article 27 of the 1961 [Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations](http://www.corpsdiplomatique.cd/VIENNA_CONVENTION_1961_ON_DIPLOMATIC_RELATIONS.pdf).

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: What is the digital footprint of a diplomatic bag.

issues.title: ISO shipping containers and related systems
issues.author: ohmantics
issues.body:
Early pre-WG use cases discussions included ISO shipping containers. They're covered by ISO 6346 with owner codes registered with [Bureau International des Containers](https://bic-code.org). The International Convention for Safe Containers established the [CSC Combined Data Plate](https://www.bic-code.org/csc-combined-data-plate/) which labels them for safety. Those come from the UN and International Maritime Organization.

https://www.bic-code.org/marking-of-containers/ goes into more detail about the ISO codes, CSC Combined Data Plate and includes an existing geofencing database used by IoT-enabled containers including a facility coding system established in ISO 9897, which itself is a coding system to describe the condition of a container including damage.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
1. Are these containers in motion, or ones sitting in some compound?
2. RFC7744.  The container is not the important part.  It's the communication to the tracking system, and the tracking system.
3. If the goal is to prevent digital attack on containers en-route, then the emblem will wind up applying to the ship.

I would make it out of scope.

issues.title: How should this draft expand on the Press case?
issues.author: amankin
issues.body:
The draft currently has a placeholder:

   Journalists in conflict zones use protective markings that indicate
   their status as a non-combatant.  Digital assets belonging to the
   press could be digitally marked, and protective markings in conflict
   zones could be digitized.

This does not even say clearly something that was articulated at IETF 124 by a stakeholder there
are distinct use cases here:  1. a digital emblem form of the PRESS marking worn by a person to mark
being a non-combatant; 2. a digital emblem marking on equipment (whether it about networked
computers/databases etc or about physical cameras, computers, sound equipment etc).  Let's use comments 
on this issue to flesh out 1. and 2. and also to reflect by the stakeholders about how much to develop these 
two sub-use-cases.

pulls.title: Add charter definitions
pulls.author: rahelFain
pulls.body: Explicitly adds the definitions for terms "(digital) emblem," bearer" and "validations" from the current charter.

comments.author: rahelFain
comments.body: Response to feedback that the definitions in the charter could change in the event that the DIEM WG is rechartered sometime in the future.

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body:
Thanks for preparing, @rahelFain, and iterating, @rohanmahy!

I must say, I don't like the "definition" of (digital) emblems in the charter. I don't find it to define anything. In the charter, this is not a problem, because we don't say: "Look, here we define what an emblem is." It's informal and glue text. This changes, however, if we copy-paste these passages into the document.

Let's look at what the definition says from a more abstract point of view:

> Emblems such as [...] can be [X]. Emblems can also be [Y].

The three sentences after that are more a problem statement that I would rather keep in the charter. These two sentences don't define anything, they only give examples of emblems.

Personally, I have two, contradictory goals:

- Have unambiguous terminology.
- Don't spend much time discussing what "digital emblems" are.

We already spent a long time during chartering trying to define digital emblems, and my feeling is that little came out of that. And I would rather sacrifice ambiguous terminology than having to spent a long time defining digital emblems.

What do you think? Is it really necessary to have a definition of digital emblems that encompass everything ever brought to the WG?

comments.author: rahelFain
comments.body:
@felixlinker My intent in adding the definition text was not necessarily to state that this was the official definition, but rather to have the referenced text explicitly copied here so that it could be referenced even if the charter were to change. (Hence the comments noting that the text is copy-pasted from the current version of the charter.) 
I'd be willing to call this something less firm than a set of definitions (say for example descriptions) and to add a caveat that later documents may more precisely define these terms - and that the sole reason for including this text was to ensure document clarity.

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body: If we move the text on DEs into the intro, that could work, for example. Just wanted to make clear that I think we should stay away from defining the term "DE." It' sa rabbit hole that we just got out off (chartering) :)

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> If we move the text on DEs into the intro, that could work, for example. Just wanted to make clear that I think we should stay away from defining the term "DE." It' sa rabbit hole that we just got out off (chartering) :)

You could also use terms like "working definition" or "temporary definition" for now.

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body:
> You could also use terms like "working definition" or "temporary definition" for now.

"Working definition" maybe, but "temporary" suggests we may want to revisit it. I think we shouldn't. This will just distract the working group without any benefit.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: Conflicts to be addressed, then OK to merge per IETF 124 discussion

```suggestion

# Requirements
```

whitespace matters in markdown!!

```suggestion
The definitions for terms "(digital) emblem," "bearer," and "validation" are reproduced from the charter {{CHARTER}} as of this writing.
```

"current" is redundant and eventually wrong..

```suggestion
```

This is no longer relevant since you have them in the next section.

```suggestion
```

These seem like requirements instead of part of the definition of "validation"

```suggestion
(Digital) Emblem:
: Emblems such as the Red Cross, Red Crescent, Red Crystal, and Blue Shield can be symbols of protection governed by International Humanitarian Law (IHL).
  Emblems can also be identified by other laws, agreements, or standards.
  There is a need to present emblems through digital communication channels.
  Emblems presented in such ways are called digital emblems.
  Digital emblems extend the range of identifying marks from the physical (visual and tactile) to the digital realm.
```

Turn into a markdown definition

```suggestion
Bearer:
: "To bear an emblem" means to present and be identified by a digital emblem.
  The entity that bears the emblem is the bearer or emblem holder.
  This is often a separate entity from the creator or original designer of the emblem.
```

Turn into a markdown definition

```suggestion

Validation:
: "To validate an emblem" means to confirm the authenticity or legitimacy of a particular symbol or design,
often by checking its details against a known standard or reference point.
  Validation may include ensuring that the bearer has not forged, stolen, or tampered with an emblem.
  Emblems may be observed by validators without the knowledge of the bearer presenting the emblem, or may be presented to a specific validator upon request.
  Cryptographic verification may or may not be used based on the in-place security mechanisms of the communication channel bearing the emblem.
  Which attributes an emblem contains, and how a digital emblem is secured and presented impacts how a validator interprets and trusts the assertions made within the emblem.
```

Turn into a markdown definition

reviews.author: felixlinker
reviews.body:
For easier reference, here my opinion as a review. I think, we're best off not aiming to define the term "digital emblem." Defining that term will just be a rabit chase without any benefit.

If we simply drop references to that term in this PR, I'm good with merging it!

pulls.title: Ready to Submit draft-ietf-diem-requirements-00 ??
pulls.author: rohanmahy
pulls.body: If the authors are ready to submit draft-ietf-diem-requirements-00 after the draft submission pause, just merge this PR and manually submit versioned/draft-ietf-diem-requirements-00.xml.

pulls.title: Simpler phrasing of undetectable validation
pulls.author: felixlinker
pulls.body: The old phrasing could have suggested that only *actual* bearers (and other parties) must not be able to detect validation. This is not what was intended. I now phrase undetectable validation w.r.t. to the discovery requirement. This should make it clear that also non-bearers must not be able to detect when someone is checking whether they are a bearer.

comments.author: dkg
comments.body:
I agree that we should change "bearers" to "potential bearers".

I don't see why we should drop issuers or authorizing parties.

```suggestion
Digital emblem discovery MAY require that potential bearers are unable to detect when an emblem is being discovered or validated.
```

pulls.title: Terminology and details on IHL use case
pulls.author: felixlinker

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body:
This pull request now incorporates a bunch of changes. I found it impossible to micro-manage parallel PRs, so this PR includes a bunch of changes to keep things simple. I think it's easier to iterate the document this way!

- It includes some terminology suggestions (edited by me, so re-review required) by Natasha Chabbra from the Australian Red Cross and Samit D'Cunha from the ICRC. Thus, addressing #6.
- It includes commits from now closed #15 to simplify some terminology.
- It partially addresses #14 and #11 for the IHL use case. There is now a stakeholder and domain model section, but critically, details on validators are missing. I will sync with Samit to get his input here.

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body: Merged PR #4 into this one for clarity.

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body: @ohmantics I added more background for the requirements of the IHL use case (as you suggested in our last call)! :)
this now says "under IHL" in two places. if the goal is to move it forward, perhaps we remove the second copy?
Thanks!

While I was added, I replaced the section reference with one that will get compiled and hence does not require keeping track of section numbering.

pulls.title: Simplify terminology
pulls.author: felixlinker
pulls.body:
Some simple changes, motivated by comments from @rohanmahy.

- Remove references to charter. I think this just complicates the document and serves no purpose.
- Remove references to requirements from charter.

Just makes everything tighter!

pulls.title: Asset/bearer
pulls.author: felixlinker
pulls.body:
I think we're best off defining asset/bearer in terms of who presents the emblem (bearer) and who the emblem applies to (asset).

For example, initially, bearers will always be domain names. However, the asset that is identified by them may not be domain names.

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body: Closes #6

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body: I think this should be merged with #8. Samit D'Cunha and Natasha Chabbra, for example, should also be contributors. Probably others too!

pulls.title: New phrasing for assets under IHL
pulls.author: felixlinker
pulls.body: @ohmantics mentioned that he found the text on assets of emblems under IHL unclear. This PR is an attempt at clarifying that. Feedback appreciated!

pulls.title: Refactor use cases section
pulls.author: felixlinker
pulls.body:
This PR depends on #20.

Two thoughts were expressed by different participants:

1. We should list as many use cases as possible.
2. We should be clear which use cases has received sufficient stake holder input, in particular, when it comes to evaluating whether its requirements are accurate and there is interest in deployment.

This PR splits the use cases section in two: One for use cases with stakeholder evaluation, and one for use cases for future reference. This split allows us to track which use case received evaluation of its requirements, but also allows us to keep use cases for future reference, as well as be explicit about what we aim to target for the extensibility requirement.

comments.author: amankin
comments.body: It is not yet a meaningful change to create a section separating out use cases like this.  I support reviewing a table of use cases versus requirements that can include a column about whether there is currently a stakeholder who has approved acknowledgement and/or has been listed in contributors - and then the WG can determine if this split is useful enough.

reviews.author: rahelFain
reviews.body:
I think this restructuring is premature.

As I see it there are use cases within the initial architecture/initial scope and others we can work on later. Prioritizing them seems to go against the entire point of this document.
As noted in the minutes from 123

"Chairs - Expect use cases and requirements doc to be relatively
comprehensive and not restricted to the charter. Prioritisation will
take place as the protocol specification is worked on, and the protocol
specification will be constrained by the charter."
(from IETF 123 minutes: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/minutes-123-diem-202507221500/ )
In practice I do think it is worth distinguishing between use cases where we have received stakeholder input and those where we haven't but would like the tone of this to be more neutral - i.e. simply stating factually that we did/did not get stakeholder input and possibly the extent of input we received.
